description.text:
I took the standard Mendel front-mount PCB sheet and put it 'flush' with the 60 degree frame rods to free up some space.
This fan mount fits the two slotted features in the std Mendel PCB sheet and assumes that your RAMPS assembly is mounted close by!
It's nice because it's nice and flexy, and if you need to fool around with your connections, just bend it away! It shall return to swifly cool those heat sinks.
Print, install, wire, cool down.

This is a tool holder for the Mostly Printed CNC that can be found here on Thingiverse.  It holds the Dremel Multi-Pro Model 275.  I made this from scratch and included the 123D files in the downloads.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

70%

The bottom mount is installed on the MPCNC with the hollow end down.  The treaded nut on the end of the Dremel is removed and the threads on the dremel are put in the hole on the bottom mount.  The threaded nut is now put back on and tightened.
The top mount is attached as shown in the pictures.
I have included the 123D design file if you wish to modify it.   If you unhide all the solids, you can see all the shapes I used to make these parts.

comments.text: I haven't used it without the lower mount.  It might work with softer materials and slower feed rates.  I suspect is wouldn't work well for most things I use it for.

description.text:
all the engines i have seen have been basic block, crank, and pistons except that one inline 4 that is up and that one is wonderfully and very nicely done but it is not a v8. so i build a v8 now i do not have a 3d printer so i was saddle unable to test print this but something i do know about the model is that i would use steel/brass rod for some of the parts i have in the files. the rod's to hold the rocker arms in place straight parts of the crank shaft the push rods really should be steel or brass. now this is not a print and put together and you are set to go thing all models will need some work when i modeled all the parts i did so with very tight tolerances the pistons are going to need to be sanded and likely most of the other parts are to so don't think of that as a print and get going think of it as a plastic modeling kit like you buy at the hobby store. the reason for the model is that i wanted a model of a engine with all the parts that work that is not a inline 4 meaning rocker heads, valves, pistons, camshaft, and all that fun stuff. but i did not make this to be a replica or a direct example of some brand of motor this is meant to depict how a v8 engine works and is meant for education and such or as a nice desk toy. if you fined any problems witch there are likely many of let me know and i will fix them i have intentions of doing similar things like this with other motors like flat engines inline engines and w engines. and if you make one or even just print a part one of the parts let me know in the comments and post a picture i would like to see how this project turns out. If you make this project or want to i recommend you scale it up by 11 or 12 to get a good size and appropriate detail. i did upload the complete engine with everything where it is suppose be so you know what it is suppose look like put together or so you can investigate it and learn how it works for yourself. Update 1.1
so what i have done is i build a intake manifold for this engine and made a set of valve covers. because of both of these both the heads and the block have been changed and updated. once i had finished the intake manifold i looked at it and thought it was no awesome enough so what do you do when a engine is not awesome enough you stick a big blower on so i did. the blower should work i wanted to make it a single pulley straight to one of the compressor blades from the crank shaft but that would put to much stress on the rods attached to the end of the compressor blades so i build a complicated series of gears that would connect the crank to the blower. i recommend to use a rubber band to connect the two pulleys that are on the front to connect the crank to the first gear in the system to tech crank. those of you that want to use a metal rode for things like that you can just stick one of the pulleys i uploaded onto the end of it and use a rubber band to connect the two. i am currently working on a v10 engine this one is going to be fuel injected or modeled as such let me know with a comment if you are looking forward to that or what you would like to see out of the v8 i have done. i have planes to create Hemi heads and piston for the same block so you can build a engine that is unique to you and the way you want it like in a video game.

this print will yes i said "will" need sanding and there is no way around that.
will likely need some drilling for the holes so you can screw it together or even just to remove some supports.
i used blender 2.75/2.77 to model this project and that is why everything is not exactly identical i free handed a lot of it that is just the way blenders work flow is like.

description.text:
Daedric Shield from Skyrim. I would start with file 1 and go to 9. The first three files are the right outside of the shield, 4-6 are the middle and 7-9 are the left outside. With 10% infill all the pieces should take about 340,673 mm of filament to make and about 46 hours to print at normal speeds. I have been slowing down all my prints from this time by 10-17% because I like print quality over speed. I'm not in any hurry to get anything done. I included the original file so you can take a peak and see the size and if it is what you are interested in. I have just started to print this and should have an update by the middle of march on how it turned out. * UPDATE **
I have almost completed printing this. I found that the handle is a bit small and come to the conclusion that Daedra have tiny hands. It you are just printing this as a wall display than this is not an issue. I will think about enlarging this and cutting up the pieces. Enjoy and good luck with this one

title: Standard Normal Distribution with Two Standard Deviation Marks

description.text:
The normal distribution with two channels in each side, at one and two standard deviations out from the mean.
Sorry for the crappy pictures, I am really bad at judging good lighting. My other recent file should give a good reference point: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1381014

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 4

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.Unsure

Infill:

20%

Notes: Brim! Use a brim. Using Cura, I just selected the Brim checkbox from the simple printing settings. I think it's 5mm.
Remove Brim Once the print is done, the brim will be attached to the edges and some will fill the channels. Using tweezers to peel it off is quite easy.

Steps Remixed ayoung's "Normal distribution sliced to show "68-95-99.7 Rule"" model by removing the numbers and splitting the pieces before sticking them all together.
I then took this piece and used it to cut out a section from a (roughly) circumscribed rectangular prism. I then used this cut out on another rectangular prism of the same size to get back to a (now much smoother) curve piece.
Then, I made a small rectangular prism (the dimensions of which I forget) and copied it six times, then used it to slice the channels in the model for the markers (cut one body using another).

This is a storage box for Weller Soldering Tips (specifically for tips for the PES51 Pencil) There are several version of the box. Weller_Tip_Box_Base.STL = Base with Tip Part# Labels
Weller_Tip_Box_Lid.STL = Lid with "Weller Soldering Tips" Label Weller_Tip_Box_Blank.STL = Base No Labeling
Weller_Tip_Box_Lid_Blank.STL = Lid No Labeling Weller_Tip_Box_Lid.STL = Plain base (no lid) that should snap fit onto the Weller Control Box. (WESD51) I have not printed this version myself so I don't know if it fits or not (I think the tabs would be to fragile anyway) but if you want to try it knock yourself out. I stuck a piece of foam in the lid to keep the shorter tips from falling out of the holes if the box was tipped over. I tried to inject paint into the lettering for the tips but it didn't come out to well.

title: GoldenGears Cabinet Door Cooking Spice Holder

description.text: This is a quick and dirty design I made to help make the spices in my cabinet easy to get to, and my cabinet less cluttered. To assemble you will need at least one set of the printed parts (obviously) and enough 1/4 inch wooden dowel (about $1 per 4 feet) to cut 3 (or 4 of you want utilize the middle rod like in the picture to be able to hold small spice containers). The length is all up to you and your cabinet dimensions, mine was around 14 inches. youll also want small screws to secure the printed brackets to the dowels. lastley you will need one of two things, either Command strips: http://www.officedepot.com/a/products/623780/3M-Command-Mounting-Strips-2-Pack/?cm_mmc=PLA-_-Google-_-Tape_Adhesives-_-623780-VQ6-47886858236-VQ16-c-VQ17-pla-VQ18-online-VQ19-623780-VQ20-99730099457-VQ21--VQ22-176197196-VQ27-9134831156&gclid=CP2-z6XgoMsCFYcYHwodw-gOUw) **Be mindful of the weight limits depending on the strips you get! OR Any mounting screws that will fit through a 1/4 inch hole. ENJOY! -GoldenGears

remixed_from.author: dutchmogul
remixed_from.title: George R. R. Martin's Cyvasse (unofficial game)

description.text:
A simple, strategic game of intrigue, tactics, economics, and warfare.   
Players quickly arrange terrain on the board, and then begin with a mere town and build their army and navy from there. Mislead enemy forces or catch them in a pincer trap, use forests and mountains to form a strong defense, and land on enemy territory with a swift navy to secure your dominion.  
See the Instructions Page for number of parts needed to print. A big shout-out to Dutchmogul for thanks in inspiration and for use of his Cyvasse mountains!

Made using Tinkercad and fumbling about in Sculptris. You will need a regular chessboard to play. You will need the following:
12 Water Tokens
3 Forest Tokens
3 Mountain Tokens
9 Forest Rings
9 Mountains
3 Peaks Each player will need the following in their color for a standard game:
8 Peasants
4 Soldiers
2 Riders
4 Boats
4 Walls
4 Towns
4 Towers
4 Fields
6 Dice (You can also use regular 12mm dice such as from Chessex) If you are playing with more than one board, multiply the above Terrain and units by the number of boards (And for the Unit and Structures choices for a custom force, it's 14 per board used instead of the above choices)

This is based on thing:1078216 which was "not optimized for printing". This has been modified fairly extensively to make it easily printable: thicker walls to give it the correct strength, tweaking the gaps to make it sturdy but flexible, slight adjustments to the slopes and orientation so it would not need supports, etc. This version of it prints satisfactorily without supports or rafts on my TAZ: the links are ready to snap together as soon as they have cooled. Once attached they rotate freely from about 90° to -30° and only come apart with deliberate effort. Unfortunately, I am not currently familiar with OpenSCAD, so it is no longer parametric, but if someone requests a parametric version, I am willing to attempt it. This is sized to be used as the cable chain for the Y axis (bed heater) cable on my Lulzbot TAZ 1, inspired by thing:1145951. I used 14 links on my printer, but I think it can work with anything between 12 and 16. The inner diameter isn't quite large enough to pass the cables with the connector attached, so I had to disconnect at the control board. I have also made anchors that connect this chain directly to the frame and bed.

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 1

No

No

0.3mm

100%

Notes: 0.35mm nozzle All the walls are thin enough that it should almost entirely consist of perimeter walls, so infill should not matter. With this nozzle the walls are mostly 5 layers thick.

description.text: My remake of an mQX quadcopter boom. I had one break when I was flying it, and needed to replace it. I tried at first to make it look like the one on the quadcopter, but it printed poorly and promptly broke on the first flight. This remix solves some of its weakness. It is quite a tight fit for the bearings and motor, so you will need to use some acetone to help it relax some (this causes the whitening of the parts in the photo). It works really well though, and I've changed all of my booms to match. I'm still thinking of remixing it further to make it print nicer, but its functional now.

With the update to Facebook, you can now express more than "like" about a post.
What better way to celebrate this update than to print out some matching coasters.
Whatever the occasion to drink, there's an emoji for it. Here's to only using "Like", "Wow", "Lol", and "Love" coasters.
(Do not consume alcohol unless you are of legal age in the area in which you live. If you drink, drink responsibly)

Doesn't Matter

No

For best results use 100%

Notes: Decide what printing method you will be using. 1 color printer. Use files which names are plain. To get the desired color effect, simply change color filament as the print gets higher. Yellow (or whatever color you choose for the face) should be the last color you print with. (Sad face printing order = Blue - Black - Yellow) 2 color printer. Choose the file names that specify 2 color printing.
3 color printer. Choose the file names that specify 3 color printing. All coasters measure 5mm high and 100mm diameter.

Modify parameters in the CONFIG section of the openSCAD file. Read the comments for hints on how to do it right. Generate the DXF.
Print. Tip: Avoid scaling the design before printing - if you do it right, you shouldn't have to!

description.text:
Note: This is deprecated, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:166045 intead A minimalist cooling solution for RAMPS: allows attaching a 60mm fan such a way it can be easily removed to tune the stepper drivers. 60mm fans are the exact same width as RAMPS and are less noisy for the same airflow than 40mm equivalent. UPDATE: v2 version (pictured in gray) is slightly taller: 27mm clearance to PCB. That allows it to sit on top of thermal fuses as well. Additional parts needed:
  • 1x 60x60 mm fan
  • 4x M3 16mm socket head screws (or 20mm depending on the fan) - 4x M3 nuts
    • Note: Watch out for the reset button on RAMPS.

I used 0.33mm PLA with 100% infill but the settings are not critical for this part and should be no challenge to print in most printers. The legs are supposed to be a slightly flexible to allow it to slide across. Note: it is symmetrical and as a result it will likely not snap in tightly everywhere because of the solder blobs or terminals that are in the way, but it should still do a good job holding the fan vibration free.

These devices are legs in which you insert a sheet of 1/4 inch (6.35mm) plywood of the size you need (i.e. for paper a 10" by 12" would have some nice size). You attach the legs on the plywood, and they are stackable so you can have as many as you want (and make each level higher if need be). 
When it comes to stacking it, you can use glue if you want, but so far mine as so tight that it is not needed. I do clean up corners with a knife as well for it to fit.
I also added an alternate version with an opening for 8th ply (3.175mm). Both openings have an extra .2mm size on the opening for a better fit.

This is a new version of Flexbot. We’ve made many changes and improvements on the basis of the previous design. For example, the design of the battery holder: the previous design would fall out easily when the copter dropped on the ground. But it would be much trouble for the user if we design it much more tightly. One day, I was listening to music with my Beats headphones when suddenly it ran out of power. I found the design of its battery part was rather special while I was changing the batteries. The cap was put in by rotating. It worked well. That’s where my idea of the 3D battery holder came from. The battery holder can hardly fall from the frame in this way. The battery part is actually very important because it plays as the landing gear of the copter. For the frame, it depends on two parts: Weight and Strength. Weight… strength…..strength……weight…..then….bang, the structure comes out. Well, that’s my hope. The process took longer than I thought, as a matter of fact. We developed many versions which did not work. Flexbot either flew unstably or fell down on the ground and crushed. The final version took many efforts. We even did the dropping finite element analysis in a simulation environment. It was quite a long way of testing and experimenting. Now the frame is good-looking (at least from my point of view), strong and neat. The new frame also embraces other changes, for example, the motor seats are wider on the top part so that it will be easier for users to push in the motors. I find 3D printing bringing much convenience to us. Whenever we want to change some details of Flexbot, I just sketch up on computer and print it out. Think about how much trouble it will be if it is by molding. That’s why we enjoyed the digital fabrication so much. It’s fun, creative and limitless. It’s good for products, and perfect for prototypes as well as testing. Currently, we are still working hard to improving the structure and and developing new relevant products. If you have any feedbacks or any ideas about Flexbot, feel free to contact us. Anything would be good. Really, I mean it, anything. Waiting for you ; ) Find us on
Twitter: https://twitter.com/flexlabshare
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/hexairbot/?ref=bookmarks
Pinterest: https://www.pinterest.com/DesignMakeShare/
Website: http://flexlab.cc/ Want to make friends and know more? Cool. Geeks together, we can spark some intelligence and bitchy ides out ; ) Flexbot is an open hardware based on Arduino. So, we are on GitHub too
https://github.com/HexAirbot And we are on GrabCAD as well. Welcome for restructuring the design~
https://grabcad.com/mylibrarymodels Video: https://youtu.be/z9GcJow3m2M About Flexbot:
Flexbot, build your own copter, learn for fun. Flexbot is a copter DIY kit for all ages. It comes with a comic book illustrating the stories and knowledge behind Flexbot. With the open source and 3D printing features, Flexbot enables us to recode the program and customize how it looks besides the fun of DIY and flying experience. What will Flexbot be like? We want you to be a part of it.

description.text: So ive been trying to think outside the box lately and come up with alternative methods in 3D printing. Mainly hoping to stumble across a great idea or inspire one. My latest test was making a spring from unprinted filament using a tool that I 3D printed. Ill be the first to admit that this is mechanically an unpractical spring. I originally made a single filament spring out of PLA (in pink). This was very weak. Less than a pound of force. I then built a tool (ABS) that would receive a spring made of 2 pcs of twisted ABS filament. I hope this experiment inspires a use for this kind of process. The springs after formed hold very good form and return to there position when stretched or contracted. I would love to see what kind of projects this idea inspires please share. I will keep posting my experiments!

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes: These settings are for the tool which will form 1.75mm filament twisted. I built this from ABS but PLA will work just fine.

Forming the spring As seen in the pictures. I took 2 equally lengths of filament (roughly 2.5 ft each). I chucked one end in my drill chuck very tight and held the other in pliers. I slowly twisted them keeping tension the whole time untill I had a cosistent tight spiral twist. I clipped off a few a couple inches on each end. I poked one end in the starting hole on the guide and hand wrapped the filament on the spring tool. Then slide the sleeve over the whole thing to capture the filament. Boil for about 20-30 seconds and rinse in cold water. Slide off sleeve and clip end of filament at the bend on the starting hole and pull off..

remixed_from.title: Y axis Bed Cable Chain for Lulzbot Taz Printers

title: Y axis / bed cable chain anchors for Lulzbot TAZ

description.text: Anchors to attach my printable cable chain to the bed and vertical strut on my Lulzbot TAZ. It requires one M5 bolt and T-slot Nut (drop in nuts work well here) and a zip tie. There are two versions of the anchor for the strut because I think the only sensible way to print this shape is in two pieces, but I have provided the complete (hard-to-print) part to show how the 'nub' should be glued to the main part (PostAnchor_Nubless). This is partially a remix of thing:1145951, which I modified it for two reasons: I wanted it to connect directly to the cable chain I made and I didn't want to have to get/use so many non-printed parts (the original required heat inserts and 7 bolts).

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Additional parts:
one M5 bolt
one drop-in t-slot nut (I used this)
about 15 compatible cable chain links Both cables need to be disconnected on the Rambo (controller box) end and removed from the existing sheath. These cables need to be fed through the entire cable chain and anchor assembly. I found it easiest to slide the links/anchors on to the wires in short sections rather than trying to push the wires through the entire chain at once. Make sure to connect the anchors to the chain before feeding the wires through and that the chain is oriented to bend the correct way (in relation to the anchors). On the bed plate side, the anchor just snaps on to the existing slot normally used to tie down the cable, leaving a small gap for a small zip tie in the middle of the anchor. On the other end, use the t-slot nut and bolt to attach to the most convenient post, taking care that the height is even with the bed anchor and that the cable chain comes off the post heading backwards (+y direction). Once the entire chain is anchored, feed the end of the wire back into the controller box and reconnect the wires.

author: rhroy

description.text:
This is a new version of Flexbot. We’ve made many changes and improvements on the basis of the previous design. For example, the design of the battery holder: the previous design would fall out easily when the copter dropped on the ground. But it would be much trouble for the user if we design it much more tightly. One day, I was listening to music with my Beats headphones when suddenly it ran out of power. I found the design of its battery part was rather special while I was changing the batteries. The cap was put in by rotating. It worked well. That’s where my idea of the 3D battery holder came from. The battery holder can hardly fall from the frame in this way. The battery part is actually very important because it plays as the landing gear of the copter. For the frame, it depends on two parts: Weight and Strength. Weight… strength…..strength……weight…..then….bang, the structure comes out. Well, that’s my hope. The process took longer than I thought, as a matter of fact. We developed many versions which did not work. Flexbot either flew unstably or fell down on the ground and crushed. The final version took many efforts. We even did the dropping finite element analysis in a simulation environment. It was quite a long way of testing and experimenting. Now the frame is good-looking (at least from my point of view), strong and neat. The new frame also embraces other changes, for example, the motor seats are wider on the top part so that it will be easier for users to push in the motors. I find 3D printing bringing much convenience to us. Whenever we want to change some details of Flexbot, I just sketch up on computer and print it out. Think about how much trouble it will be if it is by molding. That’s why we enjoyed the digital fabrication so much. It’s fun, creative and limitless. It’s good for products, and perfect for prototypes as well as testing. Currently, we are still working hard to improving the structure and and developing new relevant products. If you have any feedbacks or any ideas about Flexbot, feel free to contact us. Anything would be good. Really, I mean it, anything. Waiting for you ; ) Find us on
Twitter: https://twitter.com/flexlabshare
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/hexairbot/?ref=bookmarks
Pinterest: https://www.pinterest.com/DesignMakeShare/
Website: http://flexlab.cc/ Want to make friends and know more? Cool. Geeks together, we can spark some intelligence and bitchy ides out ; ) Flexbot is an open hardware based on Arduino. So, we are on GitHub too
https://github.com/HexAirbot And we are on GrabCAD as well. Welcome for restructuring the design~
https://grabcad.com/mylibrarymodels Video: https://youtu.be/z9GcJow3m2M About Flexbot:
Flexbot, build your own copter, learn for fun. Flexbot is a copter DIY kit for all ages. It comes with a comic book illustrating the stories and knowledge behind Flexbot. With the open source and 3D printing features, Flexbot enables us to recode the program and customize how it looks besides the fun of DIY and flying experience. What will Flexbot be like? We want you to be a part of it.

remixed_from.title: E3D V6 HotEnd CAD Models (Includes all 3 versions)

title: Customizable direct drive extruder for E3D v6 hotend for Prusa i3 / Wilson / Geeetech

description.text:
2016-03-17 UPDATE:

  • Dual extruder version!
  • Prometheus v2 hotend support (untested, set "prometheus=true" in scad to generate proper STLs)
  • Rearranged stl files
This is a simple compact mount for E3D v6 1.75mm hotend with direct extruder.
It was designed to have the following features:
  • Minimal footprint to provide the largest possible print area in all dimensions.
  • PTFE tube extends right to the extruder gear, as recommended by E3D.
  • Flexible filament support
  • Built entirely in OpenSCAD. Highly customizable and parametric.
  • Can be configured for the parts YOU have: use any drive gear and any small bearing. Just set the proper dimensions in the header.
  • Compatible with both standard "rework" X-carriage and Geeetech version.
  • Multiple mounting holes for fans, sensors, lights, etc.
  • Easy maintenance: hotend and extruder parts can be removed or replaced without disassembling the entire thing
    • Part list: (for single extruder)
  • Some PTFE tube, if it didn't come with your hot end (2mm ID / 4mm OD)
  • 2 x M3x40 screw
  • 3 x M3x16 screw
  • 2 x M3x20 screw
  • 1 x M3x10 screw
  • 1 x M3x5 flat head screw
  • 1 x M3x12 or M4x12 or M5x12 screw (depending on bearing type)
  • 1 x 4mm OD / 3mm ID / 12mm long brass tube (optional, can be disabled in config)
  • 3 x M3 nut
  • 2 x M3 washer
  • M3 thumb nut for spring tensioning (or two nuts and a wide washer, or M5x10 internal hex bolt like in Geeetech MK8 extruder)
  • MK8, MK7 or other drive gear
  • any bearing with 3-5mm ID, 9-16mm OD and 3-5mm width (603, 623, 624, 625, MR104...)
  • spring with 8-10mm diameter and 15-25mm length
  • 5015s cooling fan for PLA
    • This is a work-in-progress. So far I've only tested it with 624 bearing and MK8 drive gear. Any comments and suggestions are welcome.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes: Download the zip file, open hotend_extruder_mount.scad and configure it for your gear, bearing, x-carriage and motor. For dual extruder you need a dual base and two copies of each other item (left and right). It's better to print the extruder parts with ABS or PETG, however I printed it with PLA (except fan duct) and don't have any melting or other problems so far.

Remove supports from the filament tip. Assemble as pictured. Bearing mounting screw is supposed to self-thread into the plastic. Carefully cut the PTFE tube with a sharp knife according to the shape of the plastic tip so it's as close to the gear and bearing as possible.

My mistake,
I reasoned that if you are using the j-head, and its purpose is to run a ptfe tube from it to a extruder motor away from the carriage (bowden tube setup), you had a bowden with a very short tube (in your case) and then a tube from the top of the extruder motor to serve as a guide.

comments.text:
Looks great but my understanding is that the purpose of the bowden is to take off weight from the X-carriage thus eliminating inertia by installing the extrusion motor somewhere else.
By installing the extrusion motor on top of the carriage, more weight is added, and so defeating the purpose of the bowden.
Anyway, is a nice design.

author: invabun

description.text:
Yes. So this is the Quadcopter with the Camera on. With the FlexCam, everything will be much more fun. See the world from a different perspective. For the structure of the camera part, we made many changes. Because the former design made the camera easily broken whenever there was a crush. Now, we’ve moved the camera lens part to the frame. In this way, the camera lens can hardly be crushed when the copter lands on the ground. Flexbot is controlled by the cellphone. You can get the real-time video on your cellphone screen if you are flying the FlexCam version: ) For the other parts, we’ve as well made many changes and improvements on the basis of the previous design. For example, the design of the battery holder: the previous design would fall out easily when the copter dropped on the ground. But it would be much trouble for the user if we design it much more tightly. One day, I was listening to music with my Beats headphones when suddenly it ran out of power. I found the design of its battery part was rather special while I was changing the batteries. The cap was put in by rotating. It worked well. That’s where my idea of the 3D battery holder came from. The battery holder can hardly fall from the frame in this way. The battery part is actually very important because it plays as the landing gear of the copter. For the frame, it depends on two parts: Weight and Strength. Weight… strength…..strength……weight…..then….bang, the structure comes out. Well, that’s my hope. The process took longer than I thought, as a matter of fact. We developed many versions which did not work. Flexbot either flew unstably or fell down on the ground and crushed. The final version took many efforts. We even did the dropping finite element analysis in a simulation environment. It was quite a long way of testing and experimenting. Now the frame is good-looking (at least from my point of view), strong and neat. The new frame also embraces other changes, for example, the motor seats are wider on the top part so that it will be easier for users to push in the motors. I find 3D printing bringing much convenience to us. Whenever we want to change some details of Flexbot, I just sketch up on computer and print it out. Think about how much trouble it will be if it is by molding. That’s why we enjoyed the digital fabrication so much. It’s fun, creative and limitless. It’s good for products, and perfect for prototypes as well as testing. Currently, we are still working hard to improving the structure and and developing new relevant products. If you have any feedbacks or any ideas about Flexbot, feel free to contact us. Anything would be good. Really, I mean it, anything. Waiting for you ; ) Find us on
Twitter: https://twitter.com/flexlabshare
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/hexairbot/?ref=bookmarks
Pinterest: https://www.pinterest.com/DesignMakeShare/
Website: http://flexlab.cc/ Want to make friends and know more? Cool. Geeks together, we can spark some intelligence and bitchy ides out ; ) Flexbot is an open hardware based on Arduino. So, we are on GitHub too
https://github.com/HexAirbot And we are on GrabCAD as well. Welcome for restructuring the design~

Flexbot, build your own copter, learn for fun. Flexbot is a copter DIY kit for all ages. It comes with a comic book illustrating the stories and knowledge behind Flexbot. With the open source and 3D printing features, Flexbot enables us to recode the program and customize how it looks besides the fun of DIY and flying experience. What will Flexbot be like? We want you to be a part of it.

title: Ball and Socket Connector with Clamp Ring
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: NOTE: This project has been superseded by: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1393617 I've been working on creating a flexible gooseneck for a webcam, and ended up trying to design a hollow ball and socket connector that could fulfill the purpose. My previous attempts using TPU resulted in a workable connector, but it came apart too easily. Making the connector out of PLA resulted in a hard connector that had its own problems, and still came apart too easily. This is my latest solution. I created a ball and socket connector with grooves that allows the socket to expand just enough to stuff a ball in, and a retaining ring that snaps in place to keep the ball from popping back out. Once snapped into place, the retaining ring spins freely, meaning that there is no stress on it that would lead to early failure. However, the ring prevents the socket from expanding enough for the ball to escape from the socket. Just snap the ring back out and it once again becomes possible to remove and reinsert the ball into the socket. The ball and socket connector is hollow, allowing you to run a cable through it. As designed, the channel through the connector is 10mm in diameter, but the parts should easily scale to meet other needs. Additional upgrade: I have threaded the inside of the top ball with 14mm x 2mm ISO Metric Trapezoidal threads for the purpose of adding components to the top. Update: This has not demonstrated the holding strength that I would like, so it may be back to the drawing board. It works well at short lengths, but as it gets longer it just can't hold enough weight to be as useful as I would like. For now, I am going to try to treat the ball joints with silicone adhesive and spread it around before it dries. That may give the joint some additional holding strength.

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rafts:

After printing, you may want to polish any significant imperfections in the ball, since it will need to move within the socket.

It's not a job for someone who hasn't done much soldering. However, now that it is in place properly, I nicked off part of the cover with a blade as it stuck in too far for my board and superglued it on. Yay superglue! Anyway - it's fine now, looks good, and the SD card reader is working better than before in that it is a far more positive fit then the loose wobbly fit it was before.

description.text: After one too many session opening the base of my Thing-o-Matic and having the hex nuts fall out of the t-slots, I decided to do something about it. This design should hold the M3 hex nuts firmly in a t-slot, while still making them easy to remove if possible. The bottom of the holder also serves to spread the force from the nut to reduce potential damaging effects of compression on the wood. Because the object is small and the tolerances are pretty tight, the printing can be a little finicky. The included OpenSCAD model contains commented parameters that should make adjusting the object pretty easy. I have only printed this in ABS. It is very important that you print the holder with an infill of 100%. Otherwise the bottom layer tends not to be solid. I've had good luck printing with a thickness of 0.2mm and a width/thickness of 2.

• Print a holder
  • Insert an M3 hex nut into the hole with flats parallel to the long sides.
  • Insert the holder into a t-slot with the bottom between the nut and the incoming screw.
  • Tighten the screw.

comments.text: These are a life saver.  My 5 year old "helped me" by tightening all the bolts on the front of my TOM and pulled the nuts all the way through the slots.  After scheduling a vasectomy I printed a bunch of these and mitigated the damage.

title: Who needs HEAT?! ABS no heat bed

description.text:
See videos below!
I am testing different Bed covering that will essentially do away with the heated bed. I believe I have found the answer to this issue. I want to support this revolution. Alot of makers out there dont have heated beds. Probably more without heat than with. My solution is simple and practical. Use it or dont. Im sure there will always be a situation where heated beds are just a better choice, but this is for all you makers without heat. After I had basically taken it as a challenge I found a simple new method that assist in printing with ABS plastic when a heated bed is not an option. I used PVC Vinyl adhesive back sheet. Basically decal vinyl. I have this I bought from Amazon for my vinyl cutter.
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00345V7CI?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00 I use a glass surface on my Rostock Max so I stuck a piece to that for testing. I cleaned the glass with alcohol before applying and also cleaned the top of the decal sticker after placing for maximum adhesion. Then I started testing. Heres what I seen:
The vinyl will not lift from the glass-It will stay down the whole time
The ABS sticks extremely well to the Vinyl
I printed several files and I have minimal If no pull on the parts.
When I did see pull on sharp or small surface area pieces, I programmed a 5mm Raft with a .1 gap and it eradicated any pulling on those.
The heat from the printing actual strengthens the bond to the glass and the bond between the part and laminate as well.
There was not a file I could not get to print to my satisfaction on the vinyl.
Removing the part causes the most distorion. I did find that my method would sometimes bend the parts during removal. I want to find a more suitable method for removal Obviously, the community will test this further and really see how far this method will go. I am simply sharing my results and I hope this helps you in your printing projects

author: TTB_Studios

title: Holder for 110 negatives (for a SilverCrest SND 3600 A2)

description.text:
Some time ago I started digitizing my negatives (35mm). I have 2 scanners for this purpose (of which the SilverCrest is the fastest, but also the lesser in quality).
As I also have a lot of 110 negative strips, the idea was born to create a holder for one of my scanners.
My other scanner (an Acer Scanwit) has a very dedicated interface in which you can scan exactly 6 negatives in a fixed holder. Creating a holder for 110 negatives for this scanner seemed impossible. I therefore decided to create a holder for the SilverCrest. For this scanner the holder must be inserted and progressed manually. As you can see by the pictures and scad files I've added, I had some problems getting a decent picture.
The first version (scad and stl files with V0.1) was a good fit for the negatives and for the scanner. The problem was that I was getting a black picture. This is due to the auto white balance correction of the scanner. The plastic of the holder was displayed as pure white and therefor the image on the negative was black (see picture).
Before creating the second version, I drilled some holes in the holder, just to see if that would help (the light getting through the holes would be displayed as black, which I hoped would fool the auto white balance correction). This indeed help a bit (see pictures). Thus I created the second version (scad and stl files with V0.2).
As this version still did not let enough light trough to fool the auto white balance correction, I created another version (scad and stl files with V1.0). This version finally was good enough to fool the white balance correction of the scanner enough to create acceptable pictures from negatives. I got the best results by starting the 'acquire' cycle for every negative. Somehow the scanner is then efficiently re-triggered to create a decent picture (color and contrast).
In the mean time I successfully scanned 6 rolls of negatives (25 each). It does take some work after the scan (clipping and color/contrast adjustment), but the results are satisfactory. Enjoy!

remixed_from.author: big_red_frog
remixed_from.title: Halo 4 Helmet Full Size ( Small child )

title: Halo 4 Helmet Full Size ( Adult - 6'6" plus )

description.text: This model is now DEPRECATED by the right size version at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:158120 The following should all be considered historical. WARNING: I have a Goldilocks situation. Original model was too small, this one is too big, not horrendous and maybe the right size for master chief, but bigger than I was expecting.! THIS IS TOO BIG, you have been warned. This instance of the model is now complete, don't build it unless you are well over 7ft tall. I have added visor STL models that are only proof of concept for the the eventual vac form visor, but I will only do that step on the next proper sized version, they don't have all mounting points, but enough to show the model is "true". Will be re-sizing again, rescale, remodel will be minimal as only requires pin and magnet placement rework and checking that the walls don't become too thin. All parts are being heavily thinned as well as up-sized compared to child sized version. All parts have printed proof, please observe orientation closely to ensure minimal support implications. For Rear Left Bottom corner pieces, despite triple checking pin alignments did not clash, in the one corner the vertical and horizontal pin do! so use 5/8 tension pins instead of 3/4 tension pins in the corner to avoid the clash. Note in Jowl and chin pieces Cavity for the magnet placement to attach the chin piece which is expected to need be removable to get helmet on / off The cavity for the insertion of LEDs in the side of the Jowl. http://youtu.be/rmSNwUK0N-U Magnets used are 3/8 x 1/10 99K32.03 http://www.leevalley.com/en/wood/page.aspx?p=32065&cat=1,42363,42348 Placed in 3/8 steel cups 99K32.52 http://www.leevalley.com/en/wood/page.aspx?p=32066&cat=1,42363,42348&ap=1 Jowl Insert STL, are for simple insert with recess for the RGB candle from http://www.hero-ledstore.com/rgb-color-submersible-battery-operated-led-tealight-candle-p-1851.html Which I just use to look at aesthetics.

I am running a replicator 2.   
All sliced via makerware and standard latest makerbot firmware.  
0.2 mm layers, with support and raft.  
Please pay close attention to the orientation of pieces in the photos showing successful prints, as this is critical to the reduction in support implications, and surface finish.  
Uses 1/8 x 3/4 tension pins for location of pieces to each other, except in one case on back corner where 1/8 x 5/8 pins are required due to clash.

title: Compact Extruder for Createc 3D Psique metallic x-carriage

description.text: This is a remixed version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:725082 we adapt to our metallic x-carriage in our Prusa i3 PSIQUE kits. We have two versions, for 3mm and 1.75mm, both of them for E3D V6 hotend (original). 1.75mm version is being adapted to the use of PTFE tube, so you can mount your E3D with the PTFE tube without problems (is a work in progress, we're testing now this one). Visit us in http://www.createc3d.com or http://createc3d.com/shop

comments.text:
If you print this one, be aware that the holes for the guidler spring screws are dimensioned for a M3 Nut/Screw and not for an M4 as with most other Wade extruder kits.
M3 screws with a length of 55mm are not so easy to find...
comments.author: Maker5teve

author: createc3d

description.text:
EDIT: Added the Z carriage, modified to a more correct sizing of LM8UU fitting. I made a Wild River 240 but I really hate printed bushings.
So I modified the Y carriage to be LM8UU friendly. It's designed with some tolerance to snap fit the linear bearing.
If you'll find it too lose, I can modify it.
Exported from SketchUp Make to STL model. Now watertight, manifold, right measures (STLs originally posted from author are messy) Imported and modified in Blender, cleaned up with MakePrintable.

author: kaeverens

description.text: I made these for a stand we held at Kids Expo in Norway (For Kodegenet), where we among other things showcased 3D printing and coding for kids. The blocks where fun for the kids to play with, and it was a simple project that could show off 3D printing on a level that anyone could get and understand. The slots in the blocks are tilted slightly, so that they will snap-fit better multiple times, even when printed with PLA which is not as elastic as ABS. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/ff1kDnj44D7

Female Rail connector for popular kids toys wooden railroads. Note that these rails vary due to the material being wood.
Not suitable for children under 3 years. RISK OF SUFFOCATION! (I always wanted to write this disclaimer down).

The HeliPlane for this controller can be found here,
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1376182 Using a MindWave(EEG reader), Bluetooth to a smart device that, puts out an audio signal to an Arduino board, to turn a servo for printed parts, to rotate a pot on the controller(right side). Or, use the ring level on the other side of controller(left side). The spring loaded trainer switch on controller, determines whether the mind(EEG reader), or manual(ring lever)
input is used. While the trainer switch is down(the rest position), the ring lever(manual input) signal is used.
More info at dragonflyRC.com https://youtu.be/VyMfsE28KCA

I wanted to have my dog to wear a rollei action camera. I found thing:1001901.
I liked it, printed it and it worked, but I had some ideas how to improve it. First, I wanted to fasten the straps not crossed. Second I liked to add a fast release - and third I thougt a second mount on the chest would be a good idea :)
In my first tries I sewed the straps, which of corse works great, but a much easier way to try different straps (normal and elastic) are the smal buckles I added later. Print the harness itself, back and chest, standing up, as shown in the picture. You will have to add raft and support.
The female strap buckle also needed support here. Made for 1 inch (25 mm) strap, I use normal straps around the neck and under the chest. The long strap around the chest is an elastic one. This one tends to slip out of the lock - so I added annother buckle there. Here is a first little video made with the cam. Deshaked, cause without deshaking, you will get seasick ;)
https://youtu.be/N4cUMCP71E0
And a second one: https://youtu.be/2wxYcElcCgY Instead of makes - or as an add-on - I´d really love to watch movies you create with "my" thing and some photos of your Dogs too ;) UPDATE: Added a version back_large.stl. I changed the radius so the plate is less "curved" and so it may fit better on the back of larger dogs.

comments.text:
Hi! Your design is awesome, thank you very much.
However, it's a bit small for my 6month old GSD. I've been strapping the chest part on his molle harness for now, but it tends to rock back and forth too easily. Your back part should do the trick, however it's too "curvy" and may hurt her.
do you think you can make it with the same curve as the chest part, so it's possible for us, large dog owners, to use it?
Thanks a lot.

Enclosure For Prusa I3. The enclosure features an electronic enclosure with two 60mm Fans, A spool holder and an extractor fan.
  • All the side panels can be made with 10mm and 5mm boards of the material you want.
  • The corners are made to be printed they are all cutted into 3 pieces. They attach to the boards with screws and nuts (nut inserts are integrated).
  • Uses only M3 and M4 screws
    • Next update will be a filter box for the extractor and a power supply mount. !! This project is still in developpement. !!
